an4.173:1.1: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.
an4.173:1.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Mahākoṭṭhita sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:
an4.173:2.1: “Reverend, when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, does something else exist?”
an4.173:6.1: “Do both something else and nothing else exist?”
an4.173:8.1: “Do neither something else nor nothing else exist?”
an4.173:10.1: “Reverend, when asked whether—when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over—something else exists, you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.2: When asked whether nothing else exists,
an4.173:10.3: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.4: When asked whether both something else and nothing else exist,
an4.173:10.5: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.6: When asked whether neither something else nor nothing else exist,
an4.173:10.7: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.
an4.173:10.8: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
an4.173:11.1: “If you say that, ‘When the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, something else exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.2: If you say that ‘nothing else exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.3: If you say that ‘both something else and nothing else exist’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.4: If you say that ‘neither something else nor nothing else exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.
an4.173:11.5: The scope of proliferation extends as far as the scope of the six fields of contact.
an4.173:11.6: The scope of the six fields of contact extends as far as the scope of proliferation.
an4.173:11.7: When the six fields of contact fade away and cease with nothing left over, proliferation stops and is stilled.”
